answers.author: Denis Sullivan
answers.text:
Hello Wayne- as an OEF vet myself, I am very interested in the response to this question. Unfortunately, because of the miniscule number of people who actually serve in the military today I am not expecting much of a response at all.  According to the Department of Defense, "Just one-half of 1 percent of Americans served in uniform at any given time during the past decade -- the longest period of sustained conflict in the country’s history -- the report says. Meanwhile, as the military shrinks in size, the connections between military members and the broader civilian population “appear to be growing more distant,” the report says." Sadly, the odds of having in a vet in your workforce grow increasingly smaller. 
Having said that, I would speculate that vets ARE more likely to seek employment in the public sector, so the odds of a vet being employed by the local government are probably a bit higher than other career fields. I would hope that they are approached just like every other employee, unless circumstances (such as a disability)dictate otherwise.
Thanks!
Denis
Source cited: http://www.defense.gov/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=66253

answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
I agree with Denis that vets are more likely to seek municipal employment, and I would add that municipal employees are more likely to be vets, reservists, or Guard. But I see more potential than problems.
More than 0.5% of our (rural Virginia) job applicants are recent veterans, and especially in public works and public safety. We don't have any explicit vets preferences, but the number of veterans in our management affords understanding.  Most returning vets understand how to explain their skills and experience in civilian terms: skills in machinery, computers, supervision, and high-stress situations are impressive. Veterans often appear well qualified, and we have hired several. 
This wave of well trained and proven veterans coming home can make great contributions to civilian service.

author: Wayne Sommer
text: With the wave of returning military personnel from two war fronts, are you seeing any out-of-the-ordinary management challenges arising in your community?  If so, how are you approaching them?
title: Management Challenges to Military Reintegration
